content: your stitch under the two loops that make a teardrop shape my work is 8 inches wide and i will work until it is also 8 inches tall if it is within a half inch width to length leave it be if it is slightly more do another row or two bind off and weave in your ends once your squares have been made joining them together can turn them into something else a potholder or fingerless mittens to join to join line up your two edges see how the bumps match up to make a potholder make two squares and sew them together using only one thickness isn t enough to protect your hands you can whipstitch or single_crochet the two layers together needle join evenly whipstitch the edges together putting the needle under at least two loops work two stitches in every corner to keep them from curling up when you reach your first corner cut your yarn to about 3 inches and weave it into the fabric single_crochet join your first stitch is a ch1 to keep the single_crochet stitches flat in the corner after you ch1 single_crochet in the same stitch and in evenly across the edge when you get to the corner put 2sc in the same stitch to keep it lying flat to make fingerless mittens /wrist warmers make two squares seam each into aq tube leaving a section open for a thumbole for 26 stitch row i joined 8 stitches left 6 stitches open and joined the last 12 stitches i did this by measuring my hand wrapping the square around so the combination might be different for you be sure to work a total of 26 stitches needle join stitch the first 8 stitches together then stitch around only the bottom edge for 6 stitches before stitching the last 12 stitches together this creates the thumbhole stitch the last 12 stitches through both layers and try it on if it fits weave in your ends if it doesn t then you can adjust your seaming to the proportions you prefer work the other square the same way when you get to the end cut your yarn to about 3 inches and weave it into the fabric you can also slip_stitch or single_crochet them together a tutorial on slip stitches is on the blog i hope you ve enjoyed this pattern now that you know how to make a square the sky is the limit chain 15 working row of 14 stitches to about 4in square for a coaster chain 41 working row of 40 stitches to 18in-24in to make a placemat or hand towel experiment just remember to add/subtract your stitch count in 2 s 1sc 1dc if you would like to try other patterns you can use for squares potholders or mitts consider my free slip_stitch mitts pattern there are several free patterns on my blog geared for beginners
